article.name: Change the Landing Page on Your Phishing Campaign
article.title: Change the Landing Page on Your Phishing Campaign
article.body:
Note:We’ve added advanced features to phishing templates! All accounts will be opted in to phishing template advanced features in 2025. For more information, see our Phishing Templates Advanced Features Guide.

There are three options for setting which landing page your users will see when they fail your phishing tests: using the default landing page, a campaign-specific landing page, and a template-specific landing page. We recommend changing your default landing page for use across all phishing campaigns.

If you're looking for advice on which landing page to choose, visit our What Landing Page Should I Choose? article.

Change Your Default Landing Page

In the majority of our built-in phishing templates, clicking the simulated phishing link will lead to our system's default landing page.

You can choose a different default landing page by going to the Phishing Settings section of your Account Settings page and selecting your preferred landing page from the Default Landing Page drop-down menu.

Your default landing page will be used for all phishing campaigns unless you choose a campaign-specific landing page or set a template-specific landing page.

Choose a Campaign-Specific Landing Page

When setting up a phishing campaign, you have the option to select a landing page for that campaign.

Selecting a landing page here will override any template-specific landing pages as well as your default landing page.

If you have created an automatic, ongoing phishing campaign, you can edit the landing page for that campaign at any time.

Set a Template-Specific Landing Page

To manage, create, or edit a phishing template, click on the Phishing tab in your management console and then click on the Email Templates subtab.

You can find the template you wish to edit and click on its name. Here you can change various template-specific options as well as set a landing page. If you scroll to the bottom of the page, you will find the landing page options. You can set the drop-down menu to the landing page of your choice. Selecting a landing page here will override your default landing page.

images.alt:
This image is a security awareness training notification displayed to a user who has failed a simulated phishing test.

**Overall Design and Context:**
The interface utilizes an orange main background for high visibility and a gray footer for supplementary information. The primary text color is dark gray/black, with the main headline in white.

**Main Content Area (Orange Background):**

*   **Header:** Two lines of bold white text convey the result and purpose:
    *   "Oops! You clicked on a simulated phishing test!"
    *   "Remember these three rules to stay safe online:"
*   **Key Graphic:** A large, stylized graphic of an open white hand (stop gesture) is positioned on the right. A dark gray envelope icon is centered within the palm of the hand.
*   **Numbered Rules (Security Best Practices):** A numbered list of three rules is presented in dark gray text:
    1.  Always stop, look, and think before you click!
    2.  Check for red flags that indicate a phishing attack is happening.
    3.  Verify suspicious emails with the sender through a different medium.
*   **Secondary Instruction:** Below the rules, a reminder is provided in smaller dark gray text: "Remember: Always report suspicious emails to your supervisor or IT team. There are many ways that internet criminals will try to scam you. Stay alert—YOU are the last line of defense!"

**Footer Section (Gray Background):**

*   **Disclaimer Text:** The bottom section features a gray background with white text, providing a legal and instructional disclaimer regarding the source and scope of the test.
*   **Source and Purpose:** "Please Note: This message came from KnowBe4, Inc. Organizations that are referenced in the email message have no association with KnowBe4, Inc. and do not endorse the services of KnowBe4, Inc. The purpose of this message is to demonstrate how phishing attacks can appear to be legitimate emails from reputable companies."
images.context: lates, clicking the simulated phishing link will lead to our system's default landing page.

images.alt:
The image displays a vertical segment of a configuration form containing three parameters, each consisting of a label, a dropdown selection input field, and a dedicated help icon (a circular question mark).

1.  **Phish Link Domain:** The first field is labeled "Phish Link Domain." The active selection in the corresponding dropdown menu is "Random Domain."
2.  **Landing Page (Highlighted):** This section is prominently outlined by a thick orange rectangular border, indicating focus or selection. The label is "Landing Page." The active selection in the adjacent dropdown menu is "Default Landing Pages."
3.  **Add Clickers to:** The third field is labeled "Add Clickers to." The active selection in the corresponding dropdown menu is "Select Group."

All three input fields utilize a standard white rectangular box with a right-aligned chevron, signifying a clickable dropdown interface.
images.context: g campaign, you have the option to select a landing page for that campaign.

images.alt:
This image displays a section of a user interface (UI) featuring three input fields/widgets for configuration settings.

1.  **Landing Page:** A label titled "Landing Page" is positioned above a dropdown selection box. The current value selected is "Default Landing Page." This element is highlighted by an orange bounding box, indicating it is currently in focus or the subject of discussion.
2.  **Landing Domain:** Located to the right of the Landing Page selection, this field has the label "Landing Domain." It is also a dropdown selection box, with the current value set to "Default (terrform.com)."
3.  **Difficulty Rating:** Positioned below the "Landing Page" field, this section displays a "Difficulty Rating" label. The rating is represented by five gray, unselected star icons (outlined only, not filled). The text adjacent to the stars reads "Not Rated." Below the stars, a clickable link displays the word "Reset."
